sections.title: Night guards and occlusal splints
sections.body:
Night guards and occlusal splints are custom-made appliances designed to protect teeth and reduce strain on the jaw.

They’re commonly used where tooth wear, clenching, grinding, or jaw discomfort is present, and where doing nothing may allow problems to progress.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, splints are used thoughtfully — as part of understanding and managing forces, not as a one-size-fits-all solution.

sections.title: What to expect during treatment
sections.body:
Night guards and occlusal splints are used to protect teeth and manage risk when the bite is under strain.

They don’t “cure” grinding or clenching. Their role is more practical than that: to reduce damage, improve comfort, and help keep things stable over time when forces are higher than the teeth can comfortably tolerate.

Used appropriately, they form part of a longer-term management plan rather than a one-off fix.
bullets: We’ll take impressions or digital scans to ensure an accurate fit.
We’ll explain how and when to wear it, how to clean it, and what to expect initially.
Review appointments allow us to check comfort, fit, and effectiveness.

sections.eyebrow: When a night guard or splint may be recommended
sections.title: When a night guard or splint may be recommended
items: Night guards are often recommended for people who show signs of tooth wear, repeated fractures, jaw discomfort, or muscle tension linked to clenching or grinding.

They’re also used when we see patterns that suggest ongoing risk, even if symptoms are mild. In other words, the decision isn’t based on one sore morning — it’s based on what the teeth and bite are telling us over time.
They are not appropriate for everyone, and they are not a substitute for addressing underlying dental or bite issues where those exist.

sections.title: Our approach to splint therapy
sections.body:
Splints are most effective when they’re properly planned and reviewed.

We focus on careful assessment, accurate records, and follow-up to make sure the splint is doing what it’s intended to do. Adjustments may be needed over time as symptoms change or improve.

A splint is not usually a ‘fit once and forget’ device.

sections.title: Different types of splints
items: A night guard is a custom-made appliance that fits over the teeth and is usually worn during sleep. Occlusal splints are similar appliances, sometimes designed for more specific bite control or daytime use.
They work by altering how the teeth contact each other and by spreading biting forces more evenly. This can reduce wear, chipping, muscle fatigue, and joint strain.
The design matters. A well-made appliance is planned around your bite, not selected off the shelf.

sections.title: Comfort and adjustment
items: Wearing a night guard usually involves a short adjustment period. It may feel unfamiliar at first, and some people notice changes in how their bite feels when the appliance is removed in the morning.
The aim is comfort and protection, not forcing the jaw into a new position. We review how the appliance is working and make adjustments if needed.
Used properly, it should feel supportive rather than intrusive.

sections.title: Questions and next steps
sections.body:
Night guards are a management tool, not a permanent solution to the cause of grinding.

They need to be checked periodically, as both the appliance and the bite can change over time. Wear on the guard often tells us useful information about ongoing forces.

In some cases, additional treatment or investigation is needed. In others, long-term use of a well-maintained appliance is an effective way of protecting the teeth and supporting comfort.
bullets: If you’re unsure whether a night guard or splint is necessary, we encourage you to ask.
Understanding why an appliance has been recommended — and what it can and can’t achieve — is key to making an informed decision.

faqs.question: Will a night guard stop grinding?
faqs.answer: A night guard protects the teeth and helps manage damage from grinding, but it does not cure the habit itself. We use it as part of a longer-term management plan.

faqs.question: Are there alternatives if I do not want a splint?
faqs.answer: Management may include exercises, habit coaching, or muscle therapies, but a splint is often the safest way to protect teeth and dental work from night-time forces. We will outline all options.

faqs.question: How long will my splint last?
faqs.answer: Durability depends on grinding forces, material choice, and care. We monitor wear at reviews and advise when replacement is needed without making fixed promises.

faqs.question: How do I look after the splint?
faqs.answer: Rinse and brush it gently after use, store it in a ventilated case, and avoid heat. Bring it to appointments so we can clean and adjust it, especially if your bite changes.

faqs.question: What are the risks or limitations?
faqs.answer: Splints can feel tight or cause tenderness if contacts are uneven; adjustments resolve this. Wear or cracks may occur with heavy grinding, so periodic review is important.

faqs.question: How are night guards priced?
faqs.answer: Fees reflect the material, lab or in-house production, and the complexity of your bite. We provide a written estimate and discuss phased care if repairs or replacements are anticipated.

faqs.question: Will it affect speech or breathing?
faqs.answer: Most people adapt quickly. We refine the fit and thickness to keep speech clear and breathing unobstructed.

sections.eyebrow: When a splint may not be enough
sections.title: When a splint may not be enough
sections.body:
In some cases, a splint alone isn’t sufficient to address underlying problems.

If tooth wear is advanced, if there are structural issues with the bite, or if symptoms persist, further investigation or treatment may be needed. We’ll explain these findings clearly and discuss appropriate next steps.
